Title: the septum deviation

Amy: This is an easy one. You love this guy.
Come on, he’s an under-appreciated genius.
It’s not you. Now think, there’s a car named after him.
How about this, he’s a poor man’s Sheldon Cooper.
Hello.
Did they figure out what’s wrong?
Sheldon, it’s a routine procedure, I’ve heard you complain about his snoring.
Okay.
Don’t worry about that. I’m happy to take you to work.
It’s nice they’re getting exercise.
I’m sure he brought it.
He probably got a new one. Finish your breakfast. Look, there’s an entire section of my dashboard that doesn’t have any syrup on it.
I’m odd all the time, everyone knows that. Just last night I tried to see how many fava beans I could fit in my mouth.
Twenty eight.
Fifty six.
All right. Don’t get upset, but, an earlier appointment opened up for Leonard and he’s getting the surgery right now.
Just go to work, he’ll be fine.
Fine. It’s sweet that you care about him so much.
He wore me down. And I was distracted, he has on extra baby powder today.
Come on, let’s talk about something other than the surgery.
Stubbed his toe on the revolving door on the way in.
Who told you to keep going around?
Penny has a good point. This is like the man in the supermarket with the goiter on his neck. Whatever you’re thinking, just keep it to yourself.
And I’m sure he knew that before you held a grapefruit up next to it.
Sheldon, you can’t go back there.
Are you okay?
Don’t be like that. You two need to talk this out.
Sheldon will move out eventually.
Sheldon: Me.
Still think it’s me.
Of course there is. The Mini Cooper, ’cause it’s me.
Oh, Tesla.
Hey, how did it go?
Why would you have surgery?
But you don’t have a life-threatening condition. Why would you take the risk of surgery?
Yes, for the first five or six years, but I’ve gotten used to it. It helps me sleep. He’s like my mucus-powered white noise machine.
Very well. I’m done talking about it.
I believe it was your turn in the game.
Let’s see. Oh, this person is most famous for never having gotten his nose mutilated with elective surgery and never living the rest of his life in the shadows as a hideous, disfigured freak.
I don’t. I’m not even sure if that’s a person or a typo.
I’m listening to you snore. I’m wondering how I’ll ever sleep without it.
Really Leonard. Insults? After I spent two hours in your closet, waiting for you to fall asleep?
If the surgery is successful, the snoring is gone. And if you die during surgery, the snoring is gone.
I have to be honest with you Leonard, I’m truly worried.
Well, I’ve been doing some research and I’ve learned that one in 700,000 people die from general anaesthesia.
I suppose that’s true. You’re such a glass half-full kind of guy. I’m going to miss that.
Remember when I said if you went through with your surgery, there was a one-in-700,000 chance of dying?
Well, I’ve been crunching the numbers, and so far, I’ve gotten your probability of death all the way to a sphincter-tightening one in 300.
Leonard, what if you have an allergic reaction to the surgeon’s latex gloves?
Well, then why don’t you wear the rubber gloves I bought for you to do the dishes?
Fine. What about epilepsy?
You don’t, but the surgeon might, hmm? And your carotid artery is just one shaky scalpel away from becoming the dancing fountain at Disneyland.
I do. I have the drive to the hospital right here. That is if you make it to the car without falling down the stairs. And don’t expect me to carry you, I do that enough in life.
You don’t know that.
You know who else said that? Every cocky T. Rex currently swimming around in the gas tank of your car.
I don’t know, I’m smart and scrappy, I think I’d find a way.
Thank you. And while you’re thinking about it, if you have the surgery in Nicaragua during monsoon season, I can practically guarantee your death.
18 parts per million. And he’s still doing it.
Well, thank you. And Leonard never lets me have French toast sticks in the car. I can’t have syrupy fingers, but he can do the backstroke in a toilet bowl.
Although now that I think about it, Leonard would never go swimming in public without his swim shirt.
No, but last year, at Magic Mountain, he got such a bad sunburn, we had to cut him out of it.
You’re acting odd. Why?
Tell me the truth.
Come on.
Amy. What’s going on?
I see. Take me to Leonard.
Amy, he’s my best friend, and if you don’t take me, I’m going there anyway.
I do. And I wouldn’t be able to forgive myself if something happened to him and I wasn’t at his bedside to say I told you so.
Hello.
Oh, stop it. I assume this medical centre’s already treated the burns on your bottom from the recent pants fire.
That’s for the fire marshal to determine.
Is he okay?
Very well.
That’s a good idea. Penny, did you and Leonard ever discuss funeral arrangements?
I suppose we could try to make it a celebration, but he died so young.
Oh, this isn’t for Leonard, no. Amy bought it for me.
You know those confounded things make me dizzy.
There was a large plant in the lobby. It kept looking like the outside.
It was like a grapefruit.
Well, I’m not making any promises. Not only did Leonard take what I feel is an unnecessary risk, he deceived me.
The reason I was being a pain in the B is because I was worried about him, and no one else was.
You bet your sweet B I won’t.
And I’m not? It’s an earthquake. I knew it.
A little tremor that turns routine sinus surgery into a frontal lobotomy. Oh, I don’t care for this at all. Oh, I need to see he’s okay.
Try and stop me.
Why didn’t you stop me?
You know this is all your fault.
I told you not to get the surgery.
Wow. I don’t know which hurts worse, my nose or my heart. Well, I’m done speaking to you.

Oh, you’re hardly out of the woods, no. You still run the risk of infection, a blood clot, the possibility that an inattentive surgeon let a barn spider lay eggs in your nose. The minute you sneeze web, I’m moving out.
I was not panicked, and I am not overly attached to Leonard.
Yeah. Tell me those aren’t the words of a man with a spider eating its way through his brain. Amy, you’re a neuroscientist. Crack his skull open, spray some Raid in there.
Oh, I ordered it before your surgery. It’s the urn I was going to put you in.
I can’t send it back, I had it engraved. Here lie the ashes of Leonard Hofstadter. He thought he was right, but his room mate knew better.”
Oh, that one’s mine.
Penny: Hi.
Yeah, I watched. It was like the scary boat tunnel in Willy Wonka.
Yeah, back off, he’s all mine.
Okay. And Sheldon really believes we’re at a public swimming pool?
We had a really nice swim.
‘Cause I’m a liar, liar?
You had to tell him?
He’s still in surgery.
He’s gonna be all right. That is sticky.
I think she meant something a little happier.
Oh, it’s nice you got him that.
Okay, listen, when Leonard comes out, he is not gonna feel great, so, please don’t give him a hard time.
Okay, the reason he deceived you is you were being a pain in the ass.
Really? You won’t even say A?
Obviously, I care about Leonard. I’m gonna spend the rest of my life with him.
Sheldon, it was just a little tremor.
Come on, smile. This is gonna be my Christmas card.
Yeah, ’cause you sound really funny.
Who are you kidding? You were so panicked Leonard was gonna die, you’ll never leave him.
Yeah, once he figures out how to work a door.
Okay, that’s morbid. Send it back.
Hey, why did you get two? I’m with stupid.
Leonard: Oh, not fun. The doctor shoved a camera up into my sinuses.
Yeah. It’s a deviated septum. The surgery to correct it is simple. He’s gonna do it next week.
Because I can’t breathe. I snore, I get sinus infections.
Sheldon, I’m gonna get the surgery, it’s no big deal. End of story.
Thank you.
I think you could give a better clue.
Okay, why?
If it helps you sleep, then why are you sitting here staring at me like the albino boogeyman?
What’s your problem?
It sounds like either way, I finally get some rest.
I told you, there’s nothing to worry about.
Buddy, wh, do you realize that that also means 699,999 people don’t die?
Hey. What’re you working on?
Yeah?
Great timing. My check sphincter light just went on.
I’m not allergic to latex.
For the same reason I don’t wear the apron or the hair net.
I don’t have epilepsy, either.
Sheldon, do you realize that driving is riskier than surgery?
Buddy, I, I get that you’re worried about me and I, I appreciate that, but I’m not going to die.
Well, I do know that it won’t be from an asteroid strike.
If there was an asteroid strike, wouldn’t you die, too?
Tell you what, the surgery’s not for a week, I’ll think about it.
The doctor said I should be out of surgery by ten.
He was so busy figuring out how many parts per million of urine we’d be floating around in, he didn’t even question it.
How is it my fault?
Okay, first of all, the surgery was a success, and secondly, I didn’t even want you there.
Sheldon, I’m sorry I didn’t tell you about the surgery, but you were worried about nothing.
I never thought I’d say these words, but come on, nose spider.
You were so worried that you smashed your face trying to check on me. You love me.
Oh, what’d you get?
That’s funny. Boy, I’m gonna miss these painkillers.
Raj: Oh, so, my, uh, parents’ 40th anniversary’s coming up and I can’t think of a thing to get them.
Anyway, any ideas on a gift?
They used to like going to the Mumbai Symphony, but last year my mom thought they were phoning it in. Then my dad said based on their love life, she should know about phoning it in.
Well, they weren’t speaking at the time, so he had a servant say it to her. Oh, maybe I could make a gift for them. I know how much you guys love the coasters I made for you.
Dude, my parents just split up.
Uh, that was my dad on the phone. He moved out.

No, it’s fine. It’s not that big a deal. As long as they’re happy, I’m happy. And when I get to see them for the holidays, I’ll get to celebrate Diwali twice, one at each house. That’s double the Diwali.
How can I be okay? I come from a broken home.
I’m sorry. This is very sweet. Thanks.
Better. I guess the news just hit me a lot harder than I expected.
I think, over time, they started to resent each other, and instead of talking about the things that bothered them, they kept it bottled up, and the hate just grew.
Hey, guys. Sorry I am so late. I was on the phone with my mother.
Pretty good. She bought the book Eat, Pray, Love and used it to set my father’s Mercedes on fire. So, what’s up with you guys?
Oh, like you and I did at couples therapy.
Howard: Damn, can you imagine being married to someone for 40 years?
So I found this fencing school in Burbank that has a Jedi class. And if you’re cool being the only adults there, they said they are.
What?
Oh, my God, I, I’m sorry. I mean, if you’re not up to it, we don’t have to go out, we can just hang here.
You sure you’re okay?
You don’t look okay.
Knock, knock.
Told you, not funny.
So, how you doing?
Why? Your father barely speaks to your mother.
As you can see, we’re here to cheer you up.
What are you talking about? We’re fine. And Raj’s parents probably split up because of Raj.
They always say the children aren’t to blame, but, come on.
How can I convince you it won’t?
I’m not answering that. It’s a trap.
And here I am in the trap. You just keep talking. I’m gonna chew my leg off.
Okay. The truth is, sometimes, you’re too beautiful.
Okay, okay. I really don’t like how your wings poke me when we sleep ’cause you’re an angel.

I just don’t think the secret to a happy marriage is going out of our way to criticize each other. Although, there are ways to improve our communication. One thing I learned when I was in couples therapy was…
Not important.
Not important.
Anyway, the therapist had us tell each other what we loved about one another.
All right.
Thank you. And I love that you’re strong and independent.
I love that I’m kind of a slob around here, and you’re okay with that.
See, I am. Isn’t this great?
I love that you’re too good to pee in the kitchen sink.
And I love how your hair is always on the soap. It’s like washing myself with a hamster.
We’re just saying all the things we love about each other.
Bernadette: Not anymore.
Well, what are some of the things they like?
He said that to her?
They’re yours in the divorce.
Hi.
Oh, muffin much.
He’s just not laughing because he’s feeling blueberry. Tough crowd.
Well, of course. I would be devastated if my parents split up.
Well, at least he stuck around, not like your dad, who just took off.
Sorry, Raj. Do you have any sense of what happened with your folks?
It’s a shame they spent all that time unhappy. But sometimes, there’s muffin you can do about it. You get it, right?
Can I tell you something? This whole thing with Raj’s parents just got me a little worried about us.
What?
I’m not joking, Howie. You heard what he said about his parents. It was the little things they kept bottled up. I don’t want that to happen to us.
Well, is there anything about me you’re keeping inside?
So there are things you don’t like.
Just tell me one thing that bothers you, and I promise I won’t get mad.
Oh. Howie, be serious.
Okay, fine, maybe it was a bad idea.
Who were you in couples therapy with?
Was it your mom?
It was your mom.
Oh, that’s so sweet. I want to do that.
Okay, um, I love that you make me laugh.
And yet, I still love when you hold a door for me.
Uh-huh. And I love that I work and do all the cleaning, and you’re okay with that.
I love that you take pride in your looks, even when I have to pee in the morning, and you’re in there spending an hour on your hair.
I love that you have the confidence to speak, even without giving it an ounce of thought.
Oh, how is she?
Raj (on phone): Yes. Okay. I, I understand. Of course, yes. I’ll call you tomorrow. Bye.
